questions.text:
An 18-year-old man is transferred to your emergency department after slipping during a basketball game and hitting the right side of his face on another player’s knee. Since the incident, he has been feeling nauseated and has vomited twice. He denies loss of consciousness and is alert and oriented. A CT of the skull at the referring hospital revealed a right orbital floor fracture with minimal displacement.
On examination, the patient has 20/25 vision in both eyes, and his pupils are equal, round, and briskly reactive without afferent defect. His funduscopic examination is normal in each eye.
What is the most important next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Assess for diminished sensation in the distribution of the second branch of the fifth cranial nerve
Measure intraocular pressure
Assess extraocular motility
Obtain visual field testing
Perform fluorescein staining of the cornea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation in the second branch of the fifth cranial nerve may occur with a floor fracture and would prompt imaging, but imaging has already been performed in this case. Fluorescein staining, assessment of sensation, visual field testing, and measurement of intraocular pressure are all valid in a trauma context, but they are not the top priority in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraocular pressure may be elevated, but it is not the most important variable to assess next in this case. Fluorescein staining, assessment of sensation, visual field testing, and measurement of intraocular pressure are all valid in a trauma context, but they are not the top priority in this case.

C) CORRECT:

The most important next step in this patient is to assess extraocular motility in an effort to detect possible muscle entrapment.

In cases of entrapment, extraocular muscle manipulation can prompt the oculocardiac reflex, a vagal response that can lead to nausea, vomiting, and even bradycardia. Thus, nausea and vomiting with attempted extraocular movement should increase suspicion for muscle entrapment.

Entrapment is of particular concern in younger patients, because their bones are more pliable; a fracture in these individuals may open at impact but then snap closed (a trapdoor fracture). Although many orbital fractures do not require surgery, incarceration of tissue (muscle, in particular) in trapdoor fractures can lead to necrosis if not repaired promptly.

Key learning point: Extraocular muscle entrapment is a clinical diagnosis that may be missed without an assessment of extraocular motility.

D) INCORRECT:

Visual field testing is prudent in cases where presenting symptoms suggest abnormalities in the visual signaling pathway. Fluorescein staining, assessment of sensation, visual field testing, and measurement of intraocular pressure are all valid in a trauma context, but they are not the top priority in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluorescein staining is used to identify corneal abrasions, which typically cause foreign-body sensation, pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. Fluorescein staining, assessment of sensation, visual field testing, and measurement of intraocular pressure are all valid in a trauma context, but they are not the top priority in this case.

questions.text:
A newborn infant who was born to a mother with no prenatal care and who appeared full-term at birth after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery is seen for his first examination in the newborn nursery. He has a normal external eye examination and blinks in response to light. He has an equal pupillary response, symmetric eye movements, and an asymmetric red reflex.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s ophthalmologic care?

choices.text: Perform instrument-based screening with a photoscreener
Initiate workup for prenatally acquired infections
Refer to ophthalmology
Evaluate the urine for the presence of reducing substances
Reassure the family that the eye findings are within normal limits for a newborn

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Instrument-based screening with photoscreeners and autorefractors can be used to detect conditions that may lead to amblyopia, but this screening is not the next step in evaluating a child with red reflex asymmetry.

B) INCORRECT:

A workup for a prenatally acquired infection would be appropriate if congenital cataracts were suspected. Congenital cataracts can cause an abnormal red reflex, but the cataracts are almost always bilateral and cause bilateral absent red reflexes.

C) CORRECT:

A child with an asymmetric red reflex should be referred to an ophthalmologist immediately for further evaluation and diagnosis. An asymmetric or absent red reflex (or white papillary reflex) can be caused by abnormalities of any of the structures of the eye, including the cornea, lens, vitreous, or retina. These conditions can be vision-threatening or life-threatening.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a newborn infant with an asymmetric red reflex is referral to an ophthalmologist.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of urine-reducing substances (a screening test for galactosemia) would be appropriate if congenital cataracts were suspected. Congenital cataracts can cause an abnormal red reflex, but the cataracts are almost always bilateral and cause bilateral absent red reflexes.

E) INCORRECT:

A child with an asymmetric red reflex should be referred to an ophthalmologist immediately for further evaluation and diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy is transferred to your emergency department after slipping during a basketball game and hitting the right side of his face on another player’s knee. Since the incident, he has been feeling nauseated and has vomited twice. He denies loss of consciousness and is alert and oriented. A CT of the skull at the referring hospital revealed a right orbital floor fracture with minimal displacement.
On examination, the patient has 20/25 vision in both eyes, and his pupils are equal, round, and briskly reactive without afferent defect. His funduscopic examination is normal in each eye.
What is the most important next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Obtain visual field testing
Perform fluorescein staining of the cornea
Assess for diminished sensation in the distribution of the second branch of the fifth cranial nerve
Measure intraocular pressure
Assess extraocular motility

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Visual field testing is prudent in cases where presenting symptoms suggest abnormalities in the visual signaling pathway. Visual field testing is valid in a trauma context, but not the top priority in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluorescein staining is used to identify corneal abrasions, which typically cause foreign-body sensation, pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. Fluorescein staining is valid in a trauma context, but not the top priority in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Diminished sensation in the second branch of the fifth cranial nerve may occur with a floor fracture and would prompt imaging, but imaging has already been performed in this case. Assessment of sensation is valid in a trauma context, but not the top priority in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Intraocular pressure may be elevated, but it is not the most important variable to assess next in this case. Measurement of intraocular pressure is valid in a trauma context, but not the top priority in this case.

E) CORRECT:

The most important next step in this patient is to assess extraocular motility in an effort to detect possible muscle entrapment.

In cases of entrapment, extraocular muscle manipulation can prompt the oculocardiac reflex, a vagal response that can lead to nausea, vomiting, and even bradycardia. Thus, nausea and vomiting with attempted extraocular movement should increase suspicion for muscle entrapment.

Entrapment is of particular concern in children and adolescents because their bones are more pliable; a fracture in these individuals may open at impact but then snap closed (a trapdoor fracture). Although many orbital fractures do not require surgery, incarceration of tissue (muscle, in particular) in trapdoor fractures can lead to necrosis if not repaired promptly.

Key learning point: Extraocular muscle entrapment is a clinical diagnosis that may be missed without an assessment of extraocular motility.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old infant is brought to the Pediatric Clinic by parents who have noticed a white pupillary reflection in the right eye, especially in photos taken with flash. The infant was born at 39 weeks’ gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The newborn screen, including hearing evaluation, was unremarkable. There is no family history of ocular disease. Examination shows a diminished right pupillary red reflex. The rest of the physical exam is normal. The parents are concerned about possible serious conditions.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer for urgent ophthalmologic evaluation
Reassure parents and repeat the red reflex check at the 2-month visit
Prescribe antibiotic eye drops and reassess in 2 weeks
Obtain urgent cranial MRI

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A diminished red reflex and leukocoria in an infant are concerning for serious conditions such as retinoblastoma or congenital cataracts. These findings necessitate prompt ophthalmologic evaluation, including a dilated fundus examination and indirect ophthalmoscopy, to ensure early diagnosis and management. Early detection of conditions like retinoblastoma is crucial to prevent vision loss and improve survival outcomes.

Key learning point: An abnormal red reflex in an infant requires immediate referral to ophthalmology to rule out serious conditions such as cataracts or retinoblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Leukocoria and an abnormal red reflex in an infant raise concerns for serious conditions like retinoblastoma or congenital cataracts. Delaying evaluation risks missing early diagnosis and treatment, which are critical for preventing vision loss and addressing potentially life-threatening conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

The infant's leukocoria and diminished red reflex suggest intraocular pathology, not infection. Infectious conjunctivitis would present with signs of inflammation, such as discharge or conjunctival injection, which are absent here. Delaying evaluation with antibiotics risks missing early intervention for serious conditions.

D) INCORRECT:

Leukocoria suggests ocular conditions like retinoblastoma, but without neurological symptoms or systemic findings, cranial MRI is not immediately warranted. The priority is an ophthalmologic evaluation to assess intraocular structures directly.

questions.text: A 32-year-old welder presents with right eye pain and photophobia after welding without protective eyewear. Visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye. Slit lamp examination shows mild corneal haziness with intact epithelium, normal anterior chamber depth, and clear lens. The patient reports severe pain with lid opening and has significant blepharospasm. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Apply fluorescein dye and examine under cobalt blue illumination
Measure intraocular pressure with tonometry
Perform Seidel test to assess for aqueous leakage
Instill topical anesthetic and evert the upper eyelid to inspect for retained foreign body
Obtain noncontrast orbital CT to evaluate for intraocular foreign body

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Fluorescein staining is essential for detecting corneal epithelial defects that may not be visible on routine slit lamp examination. Ultraviolet exposure from welding commonly causes punctate keratitis with multiple small epithelial defects. The fluorescein dye stains exposed basement membrane when the corneal epithelium is damaged, making these defects visible under cobalt blue light during slit lamp examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Tonometry measures intraocular pressure and would not help diagnose corneal epithelial damage from ultraviolet exposure. While elevated pressure can occur with severe anterior segment inflammation, it is not the immediate diagnostic priority in this presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

A Seidel test is indicated when globe perforation is suspected, such as after high-velocity impact. There is no evidence of penetrating trauma in this case; the presentation is consistent with photokeratitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although lid eversion is an important part of ocular trauma assessment, the exposure history and lack of focal abrasion or metallic foreign body make ultraviolet keratitis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Orbital CT is reserved for suspected intraocular or intraorbital foreign body from high-speed metal work. This patient’s ultraviolet exposure, intact cornea, and normal anterior chamber make imaging unnecessary at this stage.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man, who works as a welder, presents with unilateral eye pain and photophobia after metal sparks hit his safety glasses. Examination shows conjunctival injection, an irregularly shaped 2-mm pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber. The patient reports seeing flashing lights, and his vision is 20/200. What is the most appropriate approach to intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement?

choices.text: Perform Goldmann applanation tonometry after adequate topical anesthesia
Use handheld rebound tonometry to avoid corneal contact
Defer tonometry until after slit lamp examination
Proceed with tonometry only if IOP appears elevated clinically
Avoid tonometry due to suspected penetrating injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Goldmann applanation tonometry requires direct corneal contact and the application of pressure. This technique is contraindicated when an open globe injury is suspected because it can cause further ocular damage and potential expulsion of intraocular contents.

B) INCORRECT:

While rebound tonometry involves less corneal contact than applanation methods, any form of tonometry that contacts the cornea is contraindicated in a suspected open globe injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Slit lamp examination may be appropriate for evaluating ocular trauma, but tonometry should be completely avoided when an open globe injury is suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Tonometry is contraindicated when an open globe injury is suspected.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- An eye with an irregularly-shaped pupil and a shallow anterior chamber following a trauma suggests an open globe injury. Tonometry is contraindicated because the procedure can worsen the injury, causing further ocular damage.
